item.title: index
item.description:
Ember Deck is a project still in early development, so this site may update and look unrecognisable after the fact!Said plainly, Ember Deck is a TTRPG Deckbuilder made for (ideally) 3-4 Player groups, but it should still scale relatively well until about 5-6 people. It was an idea heavily inspired by gems such as "Slay The Spire", "Hearthstone", "Slice and Dice", and "Morimens". The gameplay features tight resource management in a low-math, high-keyword environment, giving a couple of anchor points to make your own character and their deck unique and powerful, whereas the Setting provides plenty of opportunity for "angsty" or "against all odds" roleplay in a grimdark world, where magic is ubiquitous, but hope is scant.Once, there was HELL. Every day, souls passed in and out, getting incinerated and sent to the Hall of Echoes, pure. One day an apocalyptic event happened. Because of that, HELL is working overtime and is still centuries behind. Because of that, Souls get clogged up in the in-between, and that radiation is called magic, which seeps into the living. Until finally, their bodies can't take it anymore, and burn up from the inside.*The LORE dropdown is a good place to start for anyone curious about the world and the gritty reality found therein, ex.: VIBE. For the Rules Lawyers: here's the short end of it, as the detailed rulings fall under their own dropdowns, labelled BS, DS, or CHARACTER.Once a concept of who you'd like to play as forms in your mind, the preferable place to go is the CHARACTER>OATHS Section, where you'll find all three major Oaths (which function like classes, and determine your starting Attributes - Prisms), these in turn determine your Starting Deck.
All Oaths start with 10 BACKBONE cards making up their deck, but the keywords may vary based on chosen Oath and even subtle differences between the same Oath's decks are possible at times.
Now, having a concept, embodied by an Oath, and a Deck, you select your BURST, and your PASSIVES (Each Oath offers a different selection). These are the anchor points mentioned before - they'll define your playstyle heavily. Once that's in order, and your friends have done the same, you're set! (Don't forget to send at least 4 sentences worth of a backstory to your GM, though.) Changed Keyword function and Naming:
Empower -> Momentum.
Empower was Changed to provide a readily accessible pool instead of a small trickle.
Brace was updated to mirror this change.
Focus -> Empower.
Delay was Removed.
Ward now scales with Insight and prevents enemy keywords as well as statuses.
Added IMAGES sections across the vault to provide visuals.
CASE STUDY was removed for cleanup Certain notes have received related images inside the notes
CINDERS, and, HEARTHS AND EMBERS were moved to the FRACTIONS dropdown
The SYNC-AXIS is now more firmly tied to combat through the updated EMPOWERand BRACE keywords
BURST note was corrected, showing an improved formula for post-burst draw calculation
INVENTORY section was brushed up, adding needed specifications and removing unnecessary repetitions. Allowed Curios to have limited Mechanical value.
Clarified PIERCE's scaling
Removed false keyword scalings from GUILE, INSIGHT, and MIGHT
Clarified SHARDS in-combat effects, and removed Delay from the list.
Added the EXPLORATION section
Added Several Notes explaining the rules of EXPLORATION (NODE - RESTNODE - PATHNODE - UNKNOWNNODE - UNSTABLENODE - ENCOUNTER)
Expanded the TURNS page with an infographic, which can also be found in ENEMIES>RULINGS
Added HEARTH SHEET as well as EMBER SHEET

item.title: TURNS
EMBER SHEET
HEARTH SHEET
NODE - ENCOUNTER
item.description: A node hosting a combat or social encounter, marked appropriately depending on the hostility of the situation and the threat level.

item.title: NODE - UNSTABLE
item.description: A node that creates a one-way path once crossed, cannot be crossed again.

item.title: NODE - UNKNOWN
item.description: Its in the name.

item.title: NODE - REST
item.description: A space designated for LEVEL_UP and rejuvenation

item.title: NODE - PATH
item.description: An empty hex, allows free travel at a steady pace

item.title: EXPLORATION
item.description: Exploration is done on a Hex-grid, where the contents of specific Hexes are revealed only a short distance away, but the path as a whole can be viewed instantly (Boardgame reality) It is possible to split the party but doing so usually harbours more risk than reward.

item.title: RULINGS
item.description: Enemies operate on fixed values and unique behaviours, ignoring player Prism constraints. This allows the GM to create "impossible" threats that require specific card or behaviour answers. An enemy's "Statblock" is essentially their Intent Loop/Algorithm + their HP. Ex.: Husk - 7 HP Intent: Strike (6) -> Guard (8) -> Strike (8) -> Guard (12) -> LOOP. This makes enemies predictable (rewards knowledge/experience and learning), and decreases GM's mental load drastically, while keeping the players on their toes whenever they meet something new. Enemies are tracked through an special sheet - the Intent Table The table is reserved for enemies' names and HP tracking, while their Intent Tokens are laid out below, and resolved in the order indicated by the arrow.

item.title: SHARDS
item.description:
Shards are the universal currency of the Hearth. They act as both long-term progression and can be used as mid-combat consumables with EXHAUST:
Cost: 0 ENERGY.
Effect: Add one Secondary Non-Scaling Keyword (AREA DISCARD DRAW ECHO LIGHTNING PIERCE RETAIN VAMPIRIC.) to the next card played, OR
grant +1 ENERGY / +1 DRAW / STRIKE for 1 DMG. (Hard cap) Crushed Shards are gone forever and cannot be used for progression.

item.title: OWNER_PRIORITY
item.description: To prevent Alpha-gaming, the player who owns the card currently being played has Absolute Veto. They decide the targets, the timing, or whether to discard it for Burst charges. Negotiation and cooperation is encouraged, but the Owner's word is law.

item.title: INSIGHT
item.description: Tactical manipulation, force multiplication, and metaphysical stability. Keywords: EMPOWER, WARD, IGNITE, Mend.

item.title: MIGHT
item.description: Physical force, momentum, and brute-force attrition. Keywords: Strike, MOMENTUM, Merciless

item.title: GUILE
item.description: Precision, resource management, and reactive defense. Keywords: Guard, BRACE, Counter, BLEED

item.title: PIERCE
item.description: Ignores Block up to Value. Uses the higher Prism Value. Scales with MIGHT OR GUILE, whichever's higher.

item.title: INVENTORY
item.description:
Inventory is strictly divided to separate narrative utility from mechanical progression. Tools (~3 Slots): Functional items (Rope, Flint/Steel, Chalk, Medicine). These grant Advantage (+1 Success) on specific BS ROLLS (CHECKS). Gatekeeping: Certain tasks (climbing a sheer cliff) are impossible (DC ) without the specific item (Rope). Curios (~3 Slots): Personal narrative items or unique trophies. These usually have zero mechanical weight and exist for character flavour or narrative purposes. Share Slots with Tools. Shards (Numerical Value): Weightless essence stored directly in the Ember’s resonance. Coin Pouch: Traditional currency used for mundane trade (food, lodging, information).
Armaments (Swords, Staves, Plate) are Narrative Justifications. They do not occupy slots because they are the physical justification of your 10-card deck. A player doesn't "get a sword" for +1 DMG; they have Strike cards because they have a sword.
These are rare, non-consumable items that sit on the Hearth Sheet (Alongside VITALS, ENERGY, etc.).
They provide non-Oath Passives to the Hearth, but have either low number values, or specific conditions to make them click. Examples would Include: The Stone Heart: The Hearth is immune to the first Yellow (Disruptive) Intent of every combat.
The Whispering Coil: When the Sync-Axis is in Harmony (+3 SYNC-AXIS), Mend effects are doubled.
Heavy Greataxe: Adds Pierce to the first Strike each turn.
The Hearth can carry 3 Artifacts (Active Passives) Shards do not count toward this limit; they are stored within the "Ember" itself.

item.title: IMAGES
EROSION
item.description:
Magic doesn’t want to be inside you. Veins, fingernails, and even eyes may begin glowing in red/yellow hues. That's the usual sign of magic accumulation, which, if left untreated, can cause burnups ("treating it" means releasing the magic outward, which itself has a chance for burning the person, but also their surroundings if uncontrolled) Usually the Hearth's bond is enough to allow for venting as well as controlled releases of build up magic, but ice, water, and other means of staying cool are also in play The "end product" of the magic's effect on a human body is being turned into a Hollow - a husk-like zombie-like shell of a being A Hollow isn’t undead in the usual sense. That implies animation, will, or purpose. This is worse. Magical collapse = total loss of soul containment. What remains is: A body whose tissues have been thermally vitrified from the inside out. A mind erased by overload. A shell still moving because the residual soul-heat hasn’t dissipated yet. The Collapse Timeline Stage 1: The Burnups Chronic fever, ash coughing Skin cracking like fired clay Emotional flattening Fire responds too easily People at this stage know what’s coming. Stage 2: Breach One moment too much: A stored surge A panicked release A battlefield spike The soul-boundary fails. This is not an explosion. Explosions release energy outward. This is an implosion that's powerful enough to hit the outside too. Memory, identity, intent — gone, into the GREY MIST. Stage 3: Hollowing (fractions of a second after Breach) Organs char but don’t fail completely Blood thickens into slag Nerves fire randomly from thermal stress The heart becomes a smouldering knot The person is already dead. The body just hasn’t realized it yet. Stage 4: The Hollow Walks A Hollow: Avoids nothing Attacks nothing deliberately Moves toward thermal gradients — crowds, fires, battlefields Why? Because residual soul-heat seeks other heat to equalize with. Hollows drift toward the living. That’s why they’re exterminated on sight. Moral Baseline Shift When everyone knows: Collapse is possible Hollows exist And they were people yesterday The moral bar drops. “I’m a liar. I’m a cheat. But I haven’t collapsed.” That’s enough. Bravery gets you: Overexertion Battlefield surges Collapse Cowards: Flee early Hoard less power Survive. There is no redemption in collapse. No lesson. No chosen fate. A Hollow isn’t punished, sinful, or unworthy. They’re what happens when the system fails.



Just as Dangerous (For Different Reasons) Uncontrolled release doesn’t just burn the caster — it disturbs the local atmosphere. Side effects: Fire behaving wrong (screaming flames, fire that resembles faces) Attracting Hollows Creating permanent hot zones

item.title: HELL
item.description: Why Hell Is Full: Hell isn’t full because too many people sinned - That’s propaganda. Hell is full because it was designed as a furnace, a bottleneck for the deceased, not the final destination. Souls entered Hell to be broken down, identity stripped, meaning burned off, residual energy vented safely. At some point: The inflow exceeded processing capacity the furnace mechanisms failed Hell stopped processing souls and started storing them. Consequences? Pressure builds, exhaust backs up, heat leaks. That leak is magic. Its like the world is on top of a radioactive dump, but instead of cancer, the people get EROSION.

item.title: BS ROLLS (CHECKS)
item.description: Used to resolve arguments or environmental obstacles. Pool: 2d6 Base + Prism X d6. Success: Each die showing 4, 5, or 6. Sixes count double. Failure: Each die showing 3, 2, or 1. Ones count double. Difficulty: DC 1-2: Standard task. DC 3: Strenuous. DC 4: Dangerous/Elite. DC 6+: Near-impossible.

item.title: PASSIVES
item.description:
Regain Might VITALS at combat end.
If a STRIKE kills an enemy, all excess damage is applied to a random target.
Discarding for Burst charges grants+3 instead of +2 per ENERGY.
Whenever the Hearth takes VITALS damage, gain +1 Burst Charge.

item.title: DISCARD
item.description: Discard 1 card(s). Cards discarded this way give BURST charges equal to their cost (as if they were played), to their Owner.

item.title: UNPLAYABLE
item.description: Cards with this keyword cannot be played, only Discarded or Exhausted by the effects of other cards, BURST, or other means.

item.title: WARD
item.description: Negates the next negative STATUS or Keyword (except STRIKE) applied by an enemy. Scales with INSIGHT.

item.title: DRAW
item.description: Draw 1 card(s).

item.title: BURST
item.description:
Each player has an individual Ember Gauge (0-10). Charging: Play: +1 Charge per 1 ENERGY spent on your cards.
Sacrifice: +2 Charges per 1 ENERGY cost of a card willingly discarded from hand. You still must pay the card's cost to discard it. Activation:
Costs 10 Charges and 2 ENERGY. Burst-Lock: Only one player can trigger a Burst per turn, and the Bursting Ember cannot generate Burst Charges on the turn they used their Burst. * Additionally, when drawing cards, the player that Bursted is excluded from the calculation (N-1 x 3) for that turn.

item.title: MOMENTUM
item.description:
Pool of Value. When dealing DMG with STRIKE you may expend any amount of stacks from the pool and add it to the total STRIKE dealt. Pool decreases when HP damage is taken.
Depending on the SYNC-AXIS; Harmony - halve, rounding up. Discord - remove all stacks.
Scales with MIGHT

item.title: BRACE
item.description:
Pool of Value. When gaining GUARD you may expend any amount of stacks from the pool and add it to the total GUARD received. Pool decreases when HP damage is taken.
Depending on the SYNC-AXIS; Harmony - halve, rounding up. Discord - remove all stacks.
Scales with GUILE

item.title: EMPOWER
item.description: Adds Value to the numeric effect of the next card played. Scales with INSIGHT

item.title: PASSIVES
item.description:
When you trigger an ECHO keyword, the values are set to 2 (usually 1).
Your IGNITE effects deal damage at the start of the enemy's turn.
Allies can use your INSIGHT if its higher than theirs, when playing an INSIGHT-scaling card.
EMPOWER INSIGHT the first card played each turn.

item.title: OATH_OF_THE_CONDUIT
item.description:
Your Prism scores are as follows: 0 MIGHT
1 GUILE
2 INSIGHT You may allocate a single point to a chosen Prism. Your Starting deck consists of:
3x STRIKE
3x GUARD And,
4x EMPOWER Or;
4x MEND

item.title: PASSIVES
item.description:
Dealing unblocked HP damage grants +1 Burst Charge. Negate the first negative STATUS applied to the Hearth each combat.
Start combats with Guile Brace/MOMENTUM.
Killing an enemy draws 1 Card OR grants 1 ENERGY.

item.title: BURSTS
item.description:
Double current MOMENTUM/BRACE stacks.
Gain 2 X Might X GUARD.
Strike with MOMENTUM multiplier (DMG = Strike X MOMENTUM, instead of Strike + 1).
Mend Half Max HP, grant Might Burst charges to another Ember.

item.title: CINDERS
item.description: Just as there are the Hearthbonded Embers, there are also "stray Embers", or "Cinders". Embers without a Hearth, either because of tragedy, or neglect, they suffer alone. These individuals are a lore thing mostly, meaning - unplayable, and make for great adversaries. Ranging from "Mad geniuses" who "made it work", to individuals broken by trauma, lashing out at the unjust world. If bonding is so necessary, how do solo adversaries survive? They consume others. A Cinder doesn't have their Hearth; they seek Fuel. They kidnap low-aptitude people and "burn" through them to stabilize their own LORE/WORLD/CULTURAL PILLAR/RELIGION-PHILOSOPHY/EROSION. This gives the players a clear, gritty objective: stop the Cinder from using the local village as a life support. Cinder Status: If Cinders "lose their grip on reality," perhaps they are actually still "perceiving" the bond. They might be trying to talk to the ghosts of their former Hearth-mates, or their brains are permanently wired to receive signals that are no longer being sent. 7. Why They’re Exceptionally Powerful Power isn’t skill. It’s lack of restraint mechanisms. No bond damping No social checks No institutional oversight No long-term planning They burn hot, fast, and wrong. And they know it. Which makes them terrifyingly honest.

item.title: WET RATS
item.description: Black Market Releases, the best alternative to the CRS Because of course. Illegal venting in slums. Portable release charms. Collapse-for-hire sabotage. Most Hollow outbreaks trace back here. But the alternative, for the unfortunate, is so much worse.

item.title: CRS
item.description: Government-independent bodies that handle the population's EROSION. They set up facilities of cold stone and water to allow for safe venting, as well as taking in the "terminal" cases, which they handle out back. They wear layered uniforms, like toxic hazard workers. High-status, low-life-expectancy, trained to read early collapse signs. People accept: Lantern taxes Data indexing Witchhunt-like inspections Not because they trust authority, but because they’ve seen what happens when someone collapses in a crowd.

item.title: HEARTHS AND EMBERS
item.description:
People with spiked Prism aptitudes. The cost of power is life. Embers suffer a shortened lifespan, burning their years away the moment this flame blooms within them for the first time. Despite that, it's a gift, one that manifests randomly and powerfully, and comes at a horrid price. Players are called Embers, groups of bonded Embers are called Hearths. This bond acts as a "Resonance Buffer," preventing the individuals from "detonating" or collapsing into a Hollow state. Hearths can form due to: Rituals done by the Embers themselves, or even without the Embers' choice/knowledge via grimoires or other artifacts. Life experiences: a Bond is likely to form during a shared traumatic event, or, for the lucky ones, it can build up after years of closeness with one another. Bonding with other Embers allows for cleaner channelling - which translates nicely into extra energy per party member. Because Embers forget their pasts (due to LORE/WORLD/CULTURAL PILLAR/RELIGION-PHILOSOPHY/EROSION), they often lack a traditional moral compass. They act on instinct, immediate survival, or the orders of whoever is currently guiding them. Partially. Hearth-members (Embers) are known to have blurry memories and little recollection of who they were before the "merge". The bond between them can also be strengthened or weakened by individual interactions, even to the point of breaking (which is a traumatic experience on its own) Everyone in a hearth is a bit of an anchor to everyone else. Usually the other members are enough to "ground" whoever's having a tough time, but in times of high stress the emotions may get amplified/cascaded
Yes! It is rare to survive a bond breaking, but those who do are called CINDERS, and often lose their grip on reality, turning away from society altogether Probably the second one. I'd imagine them being like social programs, which quickly turn into military ones The most impressive and threatening Embers are those who can output the most, at the smallest cost to their vitals The "Ship of Theseus" Dilemma: If a Hearth replaces a member who died, does the new member eventually "absorb" the residual memories of the previous occupant? This could lead to haunting internal monologues where an Ember cannot distinguish their own childhood from that of a dead stranger. Cascading Failure: If emotions are amplified/cascaded during stress, a single member’s panic attack could theoretically "overclock" the entire Hearth, leading to a collective burnup. This makes emotional discipline as vital as magical talent. Hearths: Distributed Containment (And Why 3–5 Is the Sweet Spot) A Hearth is a living heat-sharing network. Soul-binding isn’t mystical romance. It’s engineering under duress. Why It Works (When It Does) Heat disperses across multiple vessels Panic dampens if others are stable Emotional regulation is forced by proximity Individual spikes become manageable averages You didn’t choose 3–5 by accident. That’s perfect: 2 is unstable (feedback loop) 6+ increases coordination failure 3–5 balances redundancy and control Someone absolutely did the math. On corpses.

item.title: THE EARTHBOUND
item.description: These zealots believe in extremist pacifism, claiming that every life spared and death delayed brings HELL closer to catching up, and ridding the world of magic and GREY MIST.

item.title: THE GREAT HEARTH
item.description: A movement striving to unite all of humanity in one giant Hearth, they believe that will stabilise everyone and bring about the harmony observed among the more stable Hearths. Their methods are faulty, unorthodox, and oftentimes forceful, which turned the public opinion against them after some disastrous attempts at joining 20 people on a city square that no longer exists...Individual identity is the problem. They talk about equilibrium and "global balance". Forced soul-binding rituals Artifact-driven mass merges City-scale bonding attempts Kidnapping Embers first (they’re “keystones”) Because every failure: Produces survivors who swear it almost worked. Creates permanent hot zones they interpret as “holy ground”. Generates Cinders they call Heralds.

item.title: IMAGES
IMAGES
GREY MIST
item.description: While EROSION comes from the unprocessed, wandering Souls, the Mist is the Will. It doesn't carry emotions, its suffocatingly cold, and imbued with memories, beliefs. Venturing into it is almost guaranteed to cause hallucinations, temporary personality disorders, and psychosis from mind-homogenisation. The leak is global. Gravity, wind, and geography don’t matter much when the source is below reality. Low light allows it to accumulate. Heat and light disperse it. Hence: Cities burn lanterns at noon Roads are lined with braziers Darkness isn’t romantic — it’s hazardous

item.title: CULTURE
item.description: Nobody riots over curfews. They riot over lantern outages. Common Saying “Don’t be a spark.” That’s an insult. Heroism gets you killed. Core Cultural Virtues Self-control Cowardice (rebranded as prudence) Predictability Collective risk minimization Wealth Is Distance From Heat Rich people: Live in well-lit districts Far from release sites Surrounded by stone, water, and warding Poor people: Live in the Mist Near old burn zones Serve as accidental heat sinks “Keep the lights on. Share the heat. Never trust a spark.”

item.title: GREY MIST
item.description: While EROSION comes from the unprocessed, wandering Souls, the Mist is the Will. It doesn't carry emotions, its suffocatingly cold, and imbued with memories, beliefs. Venturing into it is almost guaranteed to cause hallucinations, temporary personality disorders, and psychosis from mind-homogenisation. The leak is global. Gravity, wind, and geography don’t matter much when the source is below reality. Low light allows it to accumulate. Heat and light disperse it. Hence: Cities burn lanterns at noon Roads are lined with braziers Darkness isn’t romantic — it’s hazardous

item.title: HELL
item.description: Why Hell Is Full: Hell isn’t full because too many people sinned - That’s propaganda. Hell is full because it was designed as a furnace, a bottleneck for the deceased, not the final destination. Souls entered Hell to be broken down, identity stripped, meaning burned off, residual energy vented safely. At some point: The inflow exceeded processing capacity Or the furnace mechanisms failed Or Hell was damaged during a metaphysical war Doesn’t matter which. The result is the same. Hell stopped processing souls and started storing them. Consequences? Pressure builds, exhaust backs up, heat leaks. That leak is magic. Its like the world is on top of a radioactive dump, but instead of cancer, the people get EROSION.

item.title: VIBE
item.description: Low fantasy: magic is ubiquitous but weakened. People usually know someone who uses it for something more, but almost nobody can use it Well - in a controlled manner, while retaining power. Most common folk have a hard time with just one of these dimensions. Anyone can light a torch with a flick of their fingers, but someone with enough aptitude and strength to cast a ray of fire is one in a hundred, and those who survive it are one in a thousand. Dark Fantasy: The world is undoubtably a "Bad Place to Be in". People assume the worst in people, The weather usually sucks, and it is dangerous "out there" even for Embers. The environment is hostile, often shrouded in the GREY MIST, making travel suicidal without the light of a Hearth. Gritty: The players are not expected to be "heroes in shining armours, come to save the world". They can be, of course, if they will it, but morally grey and even antagonistic options are on the table still.

item.title: THE GREAT HEARTH
item.description: A movement striving to unite all of humanity in one giant Hearth, they believe that will stabilise everyone and bring about the harmony observed among the more stable Hearths. Their methods are faulty, unorthodox, and oftentimes forceful, which turned the public opinion against them after some disastrous attempts at joining 20 people on a city square that no longer exists...Individual identity is the problem. They talk about equilibrium and "global balance". Forced soul-binding rituals Artifact-driven mass merges City-scale bonding attempts Kidnapping Embers first (they’re “keystones”) Because every failure: Produces survivors who swear it almost worked. Creates permanent hot zones they interpret as “holy ground”. Generates Cinders they call Heralds.

item.title: CASE STUDY
item.description: Population: ~12,000 Status: Regional hub, not a capital Age: Old enough to be layered with mistakes The Look & Tech Level (Dieselgrim, Not Fancy) Power & Light Central oil-fired generator complex (“The Heartstack”) Network of steam pipes and fuel lines Lantern pylons every 30–50 meters Street lights burn 24/7 Backup braziers in every district Blackouts are not tolerated. Executions have happened over “maintenance failures.” Architecture Stone lower floors (fire resistance) Iron-framed upper levels Narrow streets to reduce Mist pooling Wide, well-lit plazas as thermal relief zones Everything smells faintly of: Oil Ash Hot metal No wood unless treated. The Grey Mist Situation Brightfall exists in a Mist basin. Inside the City Light keeps the Mist thin but never gone Morning fog is not normal fog Citizens wear scarves or filter masks as habit Children are taught: “If you can’t see the lantern across the street, you go home.” Outside the Walls Mist thickens within minutes Sound dampens Fire behaves erratically Road markers are lit constantly Travelers arrive shaken, coughing, or wrong. Food & Survival (This Is Where Grimdark Gets Mundane) Food Sources Root vegetables (grown underground with heat lamps) Fungal farms (Mist-tolerant strains) River fish (considered risky but protein-rich) Preserved meats (smoked heavily) Fresh fruit is: Rare Expensive Considered medicinal Food Safety Cooking isn’t just culinary. It’s sterilization: Heat kills Mist residue Raw food is taboo Fireless meals are distrusted Starvation kills fewer people than cold contamination. Living Conditions (Class Is Measured in Degrees) Upper Districts Close to Heartstack Bright, dry, noisy Lower Mist exposure Expensive rents Ember housing heavily regulated These people live longer. Lower Districts Near walls or old burn zones Lantern gaps Thicker Mist Higher collapse rates Slums aren’t lawless. They’re thermally neglected. Embers, Hearths & City Infrastructure Hearth Registry Every Hearth in Brightfall is: Registered Assigned inspection dates Required to attend cooling rites Unregistered Hearths are illegal. Not immoral. Illegal. Release Infrastructure Three public release halls One military-only vent tower Countless illegal micro-vents in slums Public release days are tense but routine. Think: Long lines Silent prayers Fire crews on standby Internal Security (Order Is Non-Negotiable) City Watch Heavily equipped with: Fire-resistant gear Cooling rods Mist dispersal grenades They are trained less to fight people and more to contain events. Collapse Response Units Separate from the Watch. Rapid deployment Authorized to kill without trial Tasked with isolating Hollow events Everyone hates them. Everyone wants them nearby. Religion & Public Space Dominant Faith: The Vigil of Ash Core beliefs: Light is duty Fire is burden Collapse is failure of care, not sin Temples double as: Lantern hubs Cooling shelters Hearth bonding sites Priests carry thermometers and ledgers. Government & Politics Governance Model Council of Fuel, Light, and Watch No single ruler All decisions filtered through risk impact Democracy exists in theory. In practice: The lanterns decide. Taxes Paid in: Coin Fuel Mandatory service rotations Miss fuel tax and your district dims. People notice. External Relations Trade Fuel imports (critical) Export: treated metals, vented slag, trained personnel Brightfall sells: people who know how to survive fire. Diplomacy Neighbors tolerate Brightfall because: It maintains roads It clears Mist paths It handles Cinders that wander too close In exchange: Tribute fuel Political leverage The Cult Problem (Because Of Course) The Great Hearth Movement has cells in Brightfall. Current Status Officially banned Quietly persistent Recruiting among: Embers Slum dwellers Collapse survivors They believe Brightfall is: “A model city—ready to be unified.” The city council is aware. They are terrified. Daily Life (The Human Bit) People: Walk briskly Avoid emotional outbursts Keep lantern oil on hand Don’t gather in darkness Children play games about: Keeping fires balanced “Don’t burn your friends” Love exists. It’s just… careful. Final Snapshot Brightfall isn’t heroic. It isn’t evil. It’s working. Which, in this world, is the closest thing to hope. Currency & Economy: Heat Is the Real Backing Forget gold standards. Gold doesn’t vent. What Money Actually Represents Currency is backed by: Light Fuel Containment capacity The more you can keep places lit and people cooled, the more stable your economy. Common forms: Fuel chits (oil, tallow, treated coal) Lantern credits Release vouchers (dangerously valuable) Heat-ration tokens for Embers Counterfeiting isn’t about metal. It’s about lying about safety. Wealth Is Distance From Heat Rich people: Live in well-lit districts Far from release sites Surrounded by stone, water, and warding Poor people: Live in the Mist Near old burn zones Serve as accidental heat sinks Class isn’t abstract. It’s thermal. Values & Philosophy: Restraint Over Virtue Heroism gets you killed. Core Cultural Virtues Self-control Cowardice (rebranded as prudence) Predictability Collective risk minimization People don’t ask: “Is it right?” They ask: “Will this raise the temperature?” Common Saying “Don’t be a spark.” That’s an insult. Religion: Containment, Not Salvation Most religions gave up on after. Now they deal with before. Mainstream Doctrine The soul is a liability Life is a containment exercise Death is a failure to manage residue Priests: Maintain lanterns Bless release chambers Conduct cooling rites Keep records of dangerous lineages Confession isn’t for forgiveness. It’s for risk assessment. Heresies (Popular Ones) Hell can be repaired Collapse is transcendence Fire purifies (these people don’t last) Government: Risk Management With Bad Optics States don’t rule. They mitigate. Core State Functions Light infrastructure Ember registry Hearth licensing Collapse response units Cinder extermination Elections, crowns, councils — flavor. The real power is whoever controls: Fuel Release sites Bonding rites Martial Law Is Permanent Not dramatic. Routine. Nobody riots over curfews. They riot over lantern outages.

item.title: THE EARTHBOUND
item.description: These zealots believe in extremist pacifism, claiming that every life spared and death delayed brings HELL closer to catching up, and ridding the world of magic and GREY MIST.

item.description: Deal 1 DMG at the end of the enemy's turn, then decrease stacks by 1. Scales with INSIGHT

item.title: LEVEL_UP
item.description:
Level-Ups occur during rests/between session, and, through SHARDS accumulated during travels allow for: Increasing a single Prism's Value (-5)
Removing Cards (-3) *A player’s deck must always contain at least 4 BACKBONE Cards.
Adding Keywords to Cards (-3 for Primary, -2 for Secondary and Tertiary, -1 for CURSES)
Purging STATUS cards (-3)
Adding new BACKBONE Cards (-2) Changing Keywords already on Cards (-2) Removing Keywords from Cards (+1)

item.title: ASH
item.description: Cost: 2 Energy. EXHAUST when played. RETAIN

item.title: STATUS
item.description:
STATUS cards are Negative effects applied by Enemies, Events, or through losing VITALS. Unless noted otherwise, these are UNPLAYABLE, and disappear at the end of combat.
STATUS cards are ownerless, and so are dealt out randomly from left to right to players with the least amount of STATUS cards in hand.

item.title: CURSES
item.description: Adding a CURSES Keyword to a card makes it add a random STATUScard into the shared deck when played, But, it reduces the card's overall cost by 2 ENERGY (effectively -1 reduction as CURSESare still technically keywords and so they increase a card's cost by 1).

item.title: VITALS
item.description:
This is the Sum of All Players' Prisms + [N (no. Players) X 2] When Vitals hits 0, the deck's top card is flipped, and the owner must decide: Shatter: Permanently remove 1 of the CUSTOMS of their choice from the pool. Trauma: The player permanently reduces one Prism by 1.
Regardless of their decision, N X STATUS cards are shuffled into the shared deck.
If the topdeck revealed card is a STATUS one itself, the player with the most BURST charge is the decisionmaker
When hit at 0 Vitals, it is also an option to Sacrifice oneself. The player's character dies, but, they release their BURST immediately, with no extra costs nor limitations. Their Cards are then taken ot of the deck, and replaced with HOLLOW.
Death can also occur when an Ember's Prism scores all hit 0. The Ember's cards are then still removed from the deck, but are not replaced with STATUS cards.

item.title: BURSTS
item.description: Reduce the cost of all cards currently dealt to 1 this turn. Next card played this turn takes effect 2 extra times (so 3 activations total). Stun an enemy. (Pause their Intent) Draw Guile cards, regain 1 ENERGY, EXHAUSTall STATUScards currently dealt.

item.title: BURSTS
item.description:
Enemy loses all GUARD and COUNTER.
STRIKE LIGHTNING BLEED/IGNITE.
Play up to INSIGHT cards for free, if they scale with INSIGHT (from other players too).
IGNITE 2 AREA (Enemies). Already IGNITE enemies take their total IGNITE stacks as DMG immediately.

item.title: CUSTOMS
item.description:
Custom Cards have more than One Keyword. Can be UNIQUE or upgraded from BACKBONE cards.
Card ENERGY Cost Scales with Keyword count (1:1), making complex cards more expensive to play.
They use only the related Prism's Value for effects, where applicable, without the BACKBONE reliability bonus.

item.title: BACKBONE
item.description: Starter Cards with only One Keyword, they have an innate +3 Value. Backbone cards are limited to the single-keyword cards provided in the Starting Oath Deck. Adding any keyword or modifying them turns them into Custom cards, removing the +3 bonus. Likewise, removing extra Keywords from a CUSTOMS card brings it back to a Backbone once its left with just One Keyword. Deck Rule: A player’s deck must always contain at least 4 Backbone Cards.

item.title: VAMPIRIC
item.description: Heal party for 1/4th Value.

item.title: WARD
item.description: Negates the next negative STATUS or Keyword applied by an enemy. Stacks.

item.title: SYNC-AXIS
item.description: The relationship between Embers dictates the combat playstyle. The scale ranges from -3 to +3, and is tied to ENERGY and DMG variables. | Level | State | Combat Bonus | Combat Penalty | |---|---|---|---| | +3 | Harmony | +3 Shared Energy per turn. | Take +1 incoming damage. | | +2 | Bonded | +2 Shared Energy per turn. | Take Full incoming damage. | | +1 | Aligned | +1 Shared Energy per turn. | Take Full incoming damage. | | 0 | Indifferent | No bonus energy. | No damage mitigation. | | -1 | Friction | 0 Bonus Energy. | Buffer: -1 DMG from all incoming hits. | | -2 | Distant | 0 Bonus Energy. | Buffer: -2 DMG from all incoming hits. | | -3 | Discord | -1 Max Energy. | Buffer: -3 DMG from all incoming hits. |

item.title: ENERGY
item.description: Used to play cards. The cost of a card equals the number of Keywords on it (Min. 1). A Party's Energy Max is calculated as follows: N (no. Players) X 2

item.title: UNIQUE
